lines.text: Well, who's a boy gonna talk to if not his mother?
I have only one thing now. Are you interested?
Well, I'd have to see it, of course.
You are seeing it. You're looking right at it.
Mrs. Langtry, something like this very rarely happens. The fine setting and workmanship usually means precious stones. It always hurts me when I find they're not. I always hope
[removes his glasses]
I'm mistaken.

Put it this way, now. Say I rent to a woman, well, she has to have a room with a bath. I insist on it, because otherwise she's got the hall bath tied up all the time, washing her goddamn hair and her clothes and everything she can think of...
If you keep out the women in the first place, see, you keep out the hookers, and then you keep out the cops, and that's how you have a clean place.
Miss Dillon, I'm sorry about our little disagreement on the phone. And I'm really sorry about your son. Well, it's hard to believe that such a strapping young man is your son.
Never mind that, just take care of him.
He's had, he's had an internal hemorrhage. He's bleeding to death.
Well, make it stop!
His blood pressure's under a hundred. I don't think he's going to make it to the hospital.
You know who I work for.
There's just so much I can do.
My son is going to be all right. If not, I'll have you killed.
I'm Roy's friend.
Yes. I imagine you're lots of people's friend.

[taking a good look at LILLY]
Oh, of course, now that I see you in the light, you're plenty old enough to be Roy's mother.
Aren't we all?
Play nice. Don't fight.
Gloucester, we are talking about breaking the law here. I just want to make sure you understand that. No one is going to get hurt, but the law is going to be broken.
Laws are made to be broken, aren't they?
Maybe I like it where I am.

Well, maybe I don't! I had ten good years with Cole, and I want them back! I gotta have a partner! I looked and I looked and believe me, brother, I kissed a lot of fucking frogs, and you're my prince!
Well, sure, Roy. You want me to drive up - ? Okay, fine, come on down. It won't be a home-cooked meal, you know.
Well, that's good news.

[trying to get an explanation for Lilly's horse bet]
You want to talk to me straight up?
My son.
Your what?
My son was in the hospital.
What the fuck are you doing with a son?
It's great to get away, isn't it? Take some time off. Next week, I'll be back to work.
You already went back to work.
What?
I watched you, working the tat on those sailor boys.
Working the what?
Oh, come on, Roy, the tat. What you do for a living.
I'm a salesman.
You're on the grift, same as me.
Myra, I'm not following you.
Roy, you're a short-con operator... and a good one, I think. Don't talk to me like I'm another square!
You talk the lingo. What's your pitch?
The long end, big con.
Nobody does that single-o.
I was teamed ten years with the best in the business, Cole Langley.
I've heard the name.
It was beautiful! And getting better all the time.
Is that right?
It is, Roy. It's where you should be. What do you bring in, $300, $400 a week? We used money like that for tips!
Don't tell me. You're Addison Simms of Seattle! And we had lunch together in the fall of 1902!
I guess I owe you my life, Lilly.
You always did, Roy.
I guess we won't be getting a straight job.
[laughing while having sex with Joe]
What're you laughing at?
broiled hothouse tomato under generous slice... of ripe cheeeeese!"
[giggles]
Some-in' wrong? Oh, I'm sorry. I thought you were the other lady.
No, I'm me.
The last modern thing I liked was the miniskirt. With technology now, nobody understands it... and that's the simple fact of the situation.
[first lines]
Around the country the bookies pay off winners at track odds. It's dangerous when a long shot comes in. Unless you have somebody at the tracks to lower those odds.
Good afternoon, Mr. Dillon.
Hi, Simms. What can I do for you?
You have a visitor, Mr. Dillon. A very attractive young lady. She says she's your mother.
You're working some angle, and don't tell me you're not because I wrote the book!
What about you? You still handling playback money for the mob?
THAT's me. That's who I am. You were never cut out for the rackets, Roy.
How come?
You aren't tough enough.
Not as tough as you, huh?
Get off the grift, Roy.
Why?
You haven't got the stomach for it.
I was hoping we could play it straight with one another.
I guess not.
I guess you won't be getting a straight job, either.
Not this week.
Not ever.
It's up to me. I'm strictly short con. It's nothing but small time stuff. I can walk away from it anytime I want.
Where have I heard that before?
Yeah, but I'm in control.

Sure. You're only 25 years old, already you can lay down four grand without even turning a hair. Grift's like anything else, Roy. You don't stand still. You either go up or down. Usually down, sooner or later.
Well, I'll let it be a surprise, then.
Do I get any say in this?
No! Because...
That's what I say. What I say is no. We don't do partners.

[Myra is hurt and confused]
What is it? What's goin' on? Why don't you wanna team up?

The BEST reason I can think of is that you scare the hell out of me. I have seen women like you before, baby. You're double-tough and you are sharp as a razor, and you get what you want or else; but you don't make it work forever. Sooner or later the lightning hits, and I'm not gonna be around when it hits you.
My God, it's your mother. It's Lilly.
What?
Sure it is. That's why you act so funny around each other.
What's that?
Oh, don't act so god-damned innocent!
[Myra is disgusted]
You and your own mother? Ugh! You like to go back where you been, huh?
Watch your mouth.
Yeah, I'm wise to you! I should have seen it before, you rotten son of a bitch. How is it, huh? How do you like it-
[Roy slaps her so hard that she falls to the floor]
I gave you your life twice. I'm asking you to give me mine once.
[last lines]
Roy, will you or won't you? What can I do to get it? Is there nothing I can do?
Lilly - Jesus, what are you doing?
Nothing at all. Nothing at all.
[Lilly swings briefcase. Roy bleeds]

[sobbing]
No, no, no, no, no, no!
Did I buy you that dress you piece of shit?
Well I guess so, you're the guy I work for.
I just washed my clothes and I can't do a thing with them.
One question. Do you want to stick to that story, or do you want to keep your teeth?
I want to keep my teeth.
